SEARCH
Package uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop

Class Signal

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop.Signal
public class Signal extends Object
A railway signal that controls whether trains can enter a section of track. Signals can be either RED (stop - do not enter) or GREEN (proceed - safe to enter).

Signals are placed at specific positions on the railway and display different graphics depending on their current state. They are used to prevent collisions and control train movement.

Example Usage:

 Position signalPos = new Position(10, 5);
 BufferedImage redImage = ImageUtil.loadImage("signal_red.png", Color.RED, "R");
 BufferedImage greenImage = ImageUtil.loadImage("signal_green.png", Color.GREEN, "G");
 Signal signal = new Signal(signalPos, Signal.State.RED, redImage, greenImage);
 
 // Check the signal before entering a section
 if (signal.isRed()) {
     // Train should stop
 } else {
     // Train can proceed
 }
 
 // Change signal to green
 signal.setState(Signal.State.GREEN);
See Also:

  • Constructor Details

    • Signal

      public Signal(Position position, Signal.State initial, BufferedImage redImg, BufferedImage greenImg)
      Creates a new signal at the specified position with the given initial state.
      Parameters:
      position - the grid position where this signal is located
      initial - the initial state of the signal (RED or GREEN)
      redImg - the image to display when the signal is red
      greenImg - the image to display when the signal is green

  • Method Details

    • getPosition

      public Position getPosition()
      Gets the position of this signal on the grid.
      Returns:
      the position of this signal

    • getState

      public Signal.State getState()
      Gets the current state of this signal.
      Returns:
      the current state (RED or GREEN)

    • setState

      public void setState(Signal.State s)
      Sets the state of this signal.
      Parameters:
      s - the new state for this signal (RED or GREEN)

    • getGraphic

      public BufferedImage getGraphic()
      Gets the graphic image for the current state of this signal. Returns the red image if the signal is red, or the green image if it's green.
      Returns:
      the appropriate image for the current signal state

    • isRed

      public boolean isRed()
      Checks if this signal is currently showing red (stop).
      Returns:
      true if the signal is red, false if it's green
